Ant doe=
sn't "leverage" much of anything from JUnit except the TestListener interfa=
ce, which it even extends because the TestListener interface doesn't specif=
y event handlers for suite starts and ends.  This is as it should be, I thi=
nk, although JUnit's junit.runner.* package could be vastly improved with a=
 small amount of work so that it's contribution to the world of test runner=
s was a little more useful.

The way to look at it is that Ant and other to=
ols built on and around JUnit like JUnitPerf, Eclipse and Artima SuiteRunne=
r *support* what has become the de facto standard API for writing unit test=
s in Java.  Funny, perhaps, that JUnit helped achieve this by shipping with=
 what I consider "reference implementation" test runners.  Think of them th=
at way and maybe your perspective will change.

JUnit's most important cont=
ribution (IMHO) are the interfaces in junit.framework.* -- not the test run=
ners, which for some reason have become the focus here.  Think of it like t=
he Servlet API or EJB or whatever.  The JCP provides an API, some tech spec=
s, and a reference implementation which allow vendors to provide containers=
 that support the API, add extra features and basically build a cottage ind=
ustry around it.
